publication.title: Global gene expression of Prochlorococcus ecotypes in response to changes in nitrogen availability
publication.description: Study combining whole-genome microarray analyses for Prochlorococcus MED4 and MIT9313, physiological measurements (chlorophyll fluorescence and photosystem II photochemical efficiency Fv/Fm), and comparative genomics to examine transcriptional responses to nitrogen starvation and growth on different nitrogen sources.
publication.abstract: We quantified changes in MED4 and MIT9313 global mRNA expression, chlorophyll fluorescence, and photosystem II photochemical efficiency (Fv/Fm) along a time series of increasing nitrogen starvation, and compared global expression under ammonium-replete conditions to expression during growth on alternative nitrogen sources. The study identified coexpressed gene clusters, showed activation of a putative NtcA regulon under nitrogen stress, and highlighted interstrain differences in carbon metabolism gene expression, suggesting distinct integration of nitrogen and carbon metabolism between MED4 and MIT9313.

publication.title: Transcriptional response of Prochlorococcus to co-culture with a marine Alteromonas: differences between strains and the involvement of putative infochemicals
publication.description: Laboratory co-culture study examining how two Prochlorococcus strains (MED4 and MIT9313) respond at the transcriptional level to interaction with a marine heterotrophic bacterium Alteromonas macleodii HOT1A3, focusing on early (20 h) gene expression changes and potential infochemical-mediated interactions.
publication.abstract: This study investigates how two Prochlorococcus strains, MED4 (high-light I) and MIT9313 (low-light IV), change gene expression in response to co-culture with Alteromonas macleodii HOT1A3. The Alteromonas strain enhances MIT9313 growth at low density but inhibits it at higher density, with no effect on MED4. Early transcriptomic responses show no nutrient-starvation signatures; MED4 downregulates photosynthesis, protein synthesis, and stress response genes, while MIT9313 upregulates these pathways. Differential expression of outer membrane modification genes, efflux transporters, and lanthipeptide-related genes (prochlorosins) suggests a targeted response to the heterotroph. Novel co-culture responsive gene families (CCRG-1 and CCRG-2) are encoded by many short genes and may be released into the medium.

publication.title: Transcriptome response of high- and low-light-adapted Prochlorococcus strains to changing iron availability
publication.description: Comparative transcriptomic analysis of MED4 and MIT9313 Prochlorococcus strains to abrupt iron starvation and rescue, assessing steady-state growth over controlled iron concentrations, whole-genome transcriptional profiling via microarrays, and locus-specific analysis of iron-stress genes and environmental distribution.
publication.abstract: Prochlorococcus contributes significantly to ocean primary productivity. The link between primary productivity and iron in specific ocean regions is well established and iron limitation of Prochlorococcus cell division rates in these regions has been shown. However, the extent of ecotypic variation in iron metabolism among Prochlorococcus and the molecular basis for differences is not understood. Here, we examine the growth and transcriptional response of Prochlorococcus strains, MED4 and MIT9313, to changing iron concentrations. During steady state, MIT9313 sustains growth at an order-of-magnitude lower iron concentration than MED4. To explore this difference, we measured the whole-genome transcriptional response of each strain to abrupt iron starvation and rescue. Only four of the 1159 orthologs of MED4 and MIT9313 were differentially expressed in response to iron in both strains. However, in each strain, the expression of over a hundred additional genes changed, many of which are in labile genomic regions, suggesting a role for lateral gene transfer in establishing diversity of iron metabolism among Prochlorococcus. Furthermore, we found that MED4 lacks three genes near the iron-deficiency-induced gene ( idiA) that are present and induced by iron stress in MIT9313. These genes are interesting targets for studying the adaptation of natural Prochlorococcus assemblages to local iron conditions as they show more diversity than other genomic regions in environmental metagenomic databases.

publication.title: Plastic leachates impair growth and oxygen production in Prochlorococcus, the ocean's most abundant photosynthetic bacteria
publication.description: Exposes two Prochlorococcus strains MIT9312 (HLII) and NATL2A (LLI) to leachates from HDPE shopping bags and PVC matting in artificial seawater; assesses growth by flow cytometry, photosynthetic efficiency (PSII), and genome-wide transcriptional changes.
publication.abstract: Plastic pollution leachates impair growth and photosynthetic capacity of Prochlorococcus. Two strains representing distinct ecotypes were exposed to leachates from HDPE bags and PVC matting. Leachate exposure inhibited in vitro growth and PSII photochemistry in a dose-dependent manner, with PVC leachates generally more deleterious. Transcriptomic analyses revealed genome-wide changes, with strain-specific differences in the timing and extent of responses, suggesting potential shifts in Prochlorococcus community composition and oceanic primary productivity.

publication.title: Genome-Wide Analysis of Light Sensing in Prochlorococcus/H17188
publication.description: A genome-wide transcriptional analysis of light sensing in Prochlorococcus MED4 using high-density Affymetrix microarrays to measure global gene expression changes under different light qualities (white, blue, red, green) and quantities, including the effects of DCMU; identification of blue-light-responsive genes and potential blue-light receptors, with discussion of redox signaling in photosynthetic electron transport.
publication.abstract: Prochlorococcus MED4 was cultured under various light qualities and intensities and subjected to high-density Affymetrix microarrays to measure global gene expression changes. Seven conditions were tested; blue light elicited a strong transcriptional response, with high white light responses resembling blue light. Results suggest blue-light sensing is mediated via a blue-light receptor, with bacterial cryptochromes as candidates, and indicate a signaling pathway linked to the redox state of the photosynthetic electron transport chain, as inferred from genes responding similarly to red and blue light and to the photosystem II inhibitor DCMU. The study discusses the adaptation of Prochlorococcus to ambient light and its implications for light-sensing repertoires in streamlined genomes.

publication.title: Phosphate acquisition genes in Prochlorococcus ecotypes: Evidence for genome-wide adaptation
publication.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
publication.description: Transcriptomic analysis of phosphate starvation responses in HL- and LL-adapted Prochlorococcus strains MED4 and MIT9313 using DNA microarrays; identification of P-starvation–induced genes, their chromosomal organization around phoB, and distribution among 11 diverse Prochlorococcus strains; comparison with a Sargasso Sea metagenomic sample to assess in situ P-acquisition gene content.
publication.abstract: The study used DNA microarrays to identify phosphate (P) starvation–induced genes in two Prochlorococcus strains, MED4 (high-light) and MIT9313 (low-light). pstS served as a marker of P limitation; MED4 showed a gradual induction of 30 genes and MIT9313 showed widespread down-regulation with 176 genes differentially expressed. Only seven up-regulated genes were shared, largely including phoB and pstABCS; a phoE-like porin downstream of phoB was induced in both strains. The results reveal two clusters of P-acquisition genes centered around phoB, with significant genome variability in the phoB region across 11 strains, not strictly correlated with rRNA phylogeny. Metagenomic data from the Sargasso Sea supported the prevalence of MED4-like P-acquisition genes in low-P environments, indicating genome-wide adaptation to P availability.

publication.title: Genome-wide expression dynamics of a marine virus and host reveal features of co-evolution
publication.description: Genome-wide transcriptome analysis of the marine cyanobacterium Prochlorococcus MED4 and its T7-like cyanophage P-SSP7 during lytic infection to elucidate host–phage transcriptional dynamics and co-evolutionary gene exchange, including cotranscription of bacterial-like metabolism genes and host gene upregulation during infection.
publication.abstract: This study investigates genome-wide transcriptional dynamics of Prochlorococcus MED4 and the T7-like cyanophage P-SSP7 during lytic infection. The phage genome is transcribed linearly with three expression clusters, and four phage-encoded bacterial-like metabolism genes (nrd, hli, psbA, talC) are cotranscribed despite their genomic separation, forming a functional unit for energy and deoxynucleotide production during replication. Host genes are upregulated during infection, many located in genome islands, suggesting host–phage co-evolution and potential gene transfer that shapes both host and phage genomes.

publication.title: Transcriptomic response during phage infection of a marine cyanobacterium under phosphorus-limited conditions
publication.description: RNA-sequencing study of Prochlorococcus NATL2A during infection by cyanomyovirus P-SSM2 under nutrient-replete and phosphorus-limited conditions; analysis of host and phage transcriptomes, identification of phage-encoded P-acquisition genes, and quantification of pstS transcript numbers per cell.
publication.abstract: The transcriptomic responses of bacteria to environmental stresses have been studied extensively, yet we know little about how stressed cells respond to bacteriophage infection. Here, we conducted the first whole transcriptome sequencing (RNA-seq) study of stressed bacteria to phage infection by infecting the marine picocyanobacterium Prochlorococcus NATL2A with cyanomyovirus P-SSM2 under P limitation, a strong selective force in the oceans. Transcripts of the P-acquisition genes in the uninfected cells were enriched after P limitation, including the high-affinity phosphate-binding protein gene pstS. They were still enriched in the infected cells under P-limited conditions. In contrast, transcripts of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) synthase and ribosomal protein genes were depleted in the uninfected cells after P limitation but were enriched during phage infection of P-starved cells. Cyanophage P-SSM2 contains pstS, and pstS and its adjacent gene g247 of unknown function were the only phage genes that were enriched under P-limited conditions. We further found that the host pstS transcript number per cell decreased after infection, however, it was still much higher in the P-limited infected cells than that in the nutrient-replete cells. Moreover, phage pstS transcript number per cell was ~20 times higher than the host copy, which may help maintain the host phosphate uptake rate during infection.

publication.title: Growth dynamics and transcriptional responses of a Red Sea Prochlorococcus strain to varying temperatures
publication.description: This study investigates how a non-axenic Prochlorococcus culture from the Red Sea (strain RSP50) responds to five temperatures (22–30 °C) by analyzing growth dynamics, cell size, DOM production and fluorescence, and performing RNA-sequencing to assess transcriptional responses during exponential growth.
publication.abstract: Prochlorococcus play a crucial role in the ocean ’ s biogeochemical cycling, but it remains controversial how they will respond to global warming. Here we assessed the response to temperature (22 – 30/C14C) of the growth dynam-ics and gene expression profiles of a Red Sea Prochlorococcus strain (RSP50) in a non-axenic culture. Both the specific growth rate (0.55 – 0.80 day/C01) and cell size (0.04 – 0.07 μm3)o f Prochlorococcus increased sig- nificantly with temperature. The primary production released extracellularly ranged from 20% to 34%, with humic-like fluorescent compounds increasing up to fivefold as Prochlorococcus reached its maximum abundance. At 30/C14C, genes involved in carbon fixation such as CsoS2 and CsoS3 and photosynthetic electron transport including PTOX were downregulated, suggesting a cellular homeostasis and energy saving mechanism response. In contrast, PTOX was found upregulated at 22 /C14C and 24 /C14C. Similar results were found for transaldolase, related to carbon metabolism, and citrate synthase, an important enzyme in the TCA cycle. Our data suggest that in spite of the currently warm temperatures of the Red Sea, Prochlorococcus can modulate its gene expression profiles to permit growth at temperatures lower than its optimum temperature (28 /C14C) but is unable to cope with temperatures exceeding 30 /C14C.

publication.title: The impact of elevated CO2 on Prochlorococcus and microbial interactions with 'helper' bacterium Alteromonas
publication.description: Co-culture of Prochlorococcus high-light II ecotype VOL4 with helper bacterium Alteromonas EZ55 under ambient (400 ppm) and elevated (800 ppm) CO2; six clonal Prochlorococcus cultures were initiated with different EZ55 populations; RNA-seq transcriptome analysis of Prochlorococcus and Alteromonas in co-culture; assessment of carbon fixation operon expression, carboxysome structures by electron microscopy, and hydrogen peroxide removal rates; investigation of microbial interactions under elevated CO2.
publication.abstract: Prochlorococcus is a globally important marine cyanobacterium that lacks the gene catalase and relies on 'helper' bacteria such as Alteromonas to remove reactive oxygen species. Increasing atmospheric CO2 decreases the need for carbon concentrating mechanisms and photorespiration in phytoplankton, potentially altering their metabolism and microbial interactions even when carbon is not limiting growth. Here, Prochlorococcus (VOL4, MIT9312) was co-cultured with Alteromonas (strain EZ55) under ambient (400 p.p.m.) and elevated CO2 (800 p.p.m.). Under elevated CO2, Prochlorococcus had a significantly longer lag phase and greater apparent die-offs after transfers suggesting an increase in oxidative stress. Whole-transcriptome analysis of Prochlorococcus revealed decreased expression of the carbon fixation operon, including carboxysome subunits, corresponding with significantly fewer carboxysome structures observed by electron microscopy. Prochlorococcus co-culture responsive gene 1 had significantly increased expression in elevated CO2, potentially indicating a shift in the microbial interaction. Transcriptome analysis of Alteromonas in co-culture with Prochlorococcus revealed decreased expression of the catalase gene, known to be critical in relieving oxidative stress in Prochlorococcus by removing hydrogen peroxide. The decrease in catalase gene expression was corroborated by a significant ~ 6-fold decrease in removal rates of hydrogen peroxide from co-cultures. These data suggest Prochlorococcus may be more vulnerable to oxidative stress under elevated CO2 in part from a decrease in ecosystem services provided by heterotrophs like Alteromonas. This work highlights the importance of considering microbial interactions in the context of a changing ocean.

publication.title: Acclimation and stress response of Prochlorococcus to low salinity.
publication.description: Two Prochlorococcus strains NATL1A (LL) and MED4 (HL) were grown across a salinity gradient to determine acclimation limits and stress responses to low salinity; transcriptomic analysis (RNA-seq) compared cells acclimated at 28 psu vs normal seawater at 34 psu; NATL1A showed more differential gene expression (525 genes) than MED4 (277 genes); low salinity affected translation, ribosomal biogenesis, ATP production, and photosynthesis genes, with idiA iron transporter upregulated in both.
publication.abstract: Prochlorococcus, a dominant marine cyanobacterium, has unclear low-salinity tolerance. This study tested salinity range of NATL1A and MED4 and acclimated them under different salinities. NATL1A could acclimate to 28 psu and MED4 to 25–28 psu; both strains experienced stress when salinity <34 psu. Global transcriptomes at 28 psu vs 34 psu showed substantial, strain-specific responses, with NATL1A downregulating translation and ATP production and upregulating photosynthesis genes, while MED4 showed opposite regulation; both strains upregulated idiA, suggesting potential iron limitation under low salinity. The results define the salinity tolerance range and reveal salinity-induced gene expression changes.

publication.title: Genome-Wide Analysis of Light Sensing in Prochlorococcus/H17188
publication.description: Study evaluating light-sensing capacity in Prochlorococcus MED4 by measuring global gene expression under seven light conditions (varying quality and quantity) using high-density Affymetrix microarrays; blue light elicited the strongest response; data suggest blue-light sensing via a blue-light receptor and potential involvement of bacterial cryptochromes, along with a redox-state signaling pathway linked to photosystem II activity.
